DrugInfoMetaData.DrugInfoDescription: Tucatinib works by binding to the part of the HER2 protein that is inside the cell, preventing it from sending signals that promote cell growth. It is a type of targeted therapy drug called a tyrosine kinase inhibitor. It is a small-molecule drug (a drug that can enter cells easily).

Section.Title: Use in Cancer
Section.Para: Tucatinib is approved to treat adults whose cancer is HER2 positive, including:

ItemizedList.ListItem: Breast cancer that cannot be removed by surgery or has spread to other parts of the body, such as the brain. It is used with trastuzumab and capecitabine in patients who have received at least one anti-HER2 treatment for cancer that has spread to other parts of the body.

Colorectal cancer that cannot be removed by surgery or has spread to other parts of the body and has the wild-type RAS gene. It is used with trastuzumab in patients who have received treatment that included a fluoropyrimidine, oxaliplatin, and irinotecan hydrochloride and it did not work or is no longer working.¹

Section.Para: ¹This use is approved under FDA’s Accelerated Approval Program. As a condition of approval, a confirmatory trial(s) must show that tucatinib provides a clinical benefit in these patients.
Tucatinib is also being studied in the treatment of other types of cancer.
